Hayne's 'monster' punt return Former NRL star Jarryd Hayne impresses on the field with a "monster" 37-yard punt return against the Arizona Cardinals.
PT0M58S 620 349 A leading US sports scientist has used the analogy of Roger Bannister's feat of becoming the first man to complete a four-minute mile to describe Jarryd Hayne's achievement of making the switch from rugby league to the NFL.
Dr John Sullivan is in Australia ahead of this weekend's AFL Draft Combine and has worked in the NFL for the last 14 years, as well as teams from NCAA College Football and the English Premier League.
He specialises in talent identification and will work with the AFL on behalf of high-performance brand 2XU to gauge the degree of talent in Australia as well help them implement strategies and methods to identify talent.
Pioneer: Roger Bannister breaks the four-minute mile. Photo: Getty Images
Sullivan was certain rugby league and AFL stars had the physical capabilities to make it in the NFL, but said there might be more belief after what Hayne has been able to achieve.
Advertisement "Once someone does it, it opens up the eyes and ears of many to what is possible," Sullivan said. "You could liken it in some ways to Roger Bannister. Bannister broke the sub four-minute mile and in the six months after that, 18 others did because he opened the eyes to what is possible. It was not a physical limitation, it was an idea, and that is what Jarryd Hayne has done - he's planted a different idea. A number of players are probably going to want to do what he's done."
Sullivan made the point Australia has had at least one AFL player in the NFL since the 1950s, and said playing in the NFL was not a new phenomenon for Australian athletes.
American dream: Former NRL player Jarryd Hayne. Photo: Getty Images
Asked which current rugby league or AFL star he thought would be best suited to the NFL, Sullivan would not be drawn into specific players and said US talent scouts also would not risk such a thing.
"The talent is being looked at, but they're not going to talk about it until they pull the trigger," Sullivan said. "Because recruiting and analysing talent gets very competitive, it will not be discussed because someone wants to find the diamonds in the rough on the other side of the world. It's just not discussed openly. Much of recruiting in the NFL is done in that way or in North America. We tend to say less and treat it like a corporate or military structure."
Sullivan likened the NFL's plan to expand its talent pool to that of the NBA, and will be encouraging NFL franchises to look into the calibre of athletes, like Hayne, Australia can produce.
"It's about seeing the talent which is beyond our continental shores," he said. "And I think by saying: 'Hey, go take a look', seeing is believing. We'll get plenty of teams who are open-minded by that, some that would not, but they'll be the ones who miss out. There are plenty of talented athletes here.
"Hayne's physical attributes don't amaze me. What amazed me is the cognitive ability for him to learn a playbook that is probably three and a half inches thick. To not be familiar with the language, the play design, the structure...to have to intellectual fortitude, to have the learning ability and the emotional recovery to play calm is what amazes me."
